COVID-19: Food Safety and Delivery Guidelines
Accepting deliveries and takeout orders

Limit in-person contact if possible.
Pay online or on the phone when you order (if possible).
Accept deliveries without in-person contact whenever possible. Ask for deliveries to be left in a safe spot outside your house (such as your front porch or lobby), with no person-to-person interaction. Otherwise, stay at least 6 feet away from the delivery person.

After receiving your delivery or bringing home your takeout food, as well as after collecting mail from the post office or home mailbox, wash your hands with soap and water for 20 seconds. If soap and water are not available, use a hand sanitizer with at least 60% alcohol.

Links for staff and families regarding COVID-19 and food safety and receiving deliveries at home:

https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/daily-life-coping/essential-goods-services.html

Dear Families,
The speed of change during the past few weeks has left all of us feeling unanchored. A little more than three weeks ago, school was still in session, and everyone was beginning to show signs of restlessness in anticipation of a spring break. High school seniors were beginning to use the term "senioritis," and looking forward to many treasured traditions and rites of passage on the way to graduation.

We now know from Governor Kate Brown’s announcement earlier today that schools will be closed for the remainder of the school year. While we understand the health and safety reasons for this directive, we are deeply saddened by the loss. We so looked forward to being together again as a learning community before the summer months.

Continue reading the full letter from the Superintendent at https://www.ocsd62.org/district/schools-remain-closed-new-2020-grad-guidance

Stacy Erickson, a West Linn educator, will be the new Associate Principal of Oregon City High School.

Erickson holds a doctorate in education from the University of Oregon and a masters degree in teaching from Lewis & Clark College. She is the parent of three grown sons, a teacher, a graduate student, and a junior at the University of Oregon.

She has worked at West Linn High School since 1995 as a social studies teacher and a librarian. Most recently she served as the Academic Success Coordinator at West Linn-Wilsonville’s Arts and Technology High School.

“I am excited to be a part of this amazing school community and feel lucky to have the chance to serve here,” said Erickson. “This school district is accomplishing great things because of its care and concern for all students."

"We are fortunate to bring Stacy on to our school leadership team,” said Principal Carey Wilhelm. “She brings enthusiasm and a real passion for student success."

She has worked at West Linn High School since 1995 as a social studies teacher and a librarian. Most recently she served as the Academic Success Coordinator at West Linn-Wilsonville’s Arts and Technology High School.

“I am excited to be a part of this amazing school community and feel lucky to have the chance to serve here,” said Erickson. “This school district is accomplishing great things because of its care and concern for all students."

"We are fortunate to bring Stacy on to our school leadership team,” said Principal Carey Wilhelm. “She brings enthusiasm and a real passion for student success."

For homeless teens and unaccompanied minors, finishing high school can be an enormous challenge. Thanks to a new partnership between Oregon City Schools and the volunteer program Second Home, students in this situation now have a better chance of success.

Second Home, a project of Ecumenical Ministries of Oregon, finds volunteers in the community who can share space in their home and provide food to teens who want to finish their high school education. Students reciprocate by helping with household chores.

“Last year, we had 280 homeless students in Oregon City Schools, and of those, 116 were unaccompanied youths at some point,” said homeless liaison Mary Ellen Winterhalter. “The huge advantages of this program are that students gain the stability and support of having a regular place to stay while they finish their high school education. Also they get the opportunity for a positive rental referral that is helpful later, when they look for a place of their own.”

To find out more, contact Adam Jenkins at 503.261.4583.

Janet Whitney was a physical education and health teacher, coach, and athletic director at Gardiner Middle School for more than 32 years. After her death in 2018, her family created a scholarship fund in her memory.

The family contributed more than $41,000 to endow a scholarship through the Oregon Community Foundation. Starting next year, it will support young women graduates from the Oregon City School District who wish to pursue a degree in physical education or a closely related field.

“Physical education and health education make a big impact on students, encouraging fitness, nutrition, and healthy choices that impact students their whole lives,” said Oregon City High School Principal Tom Lovell.

“Janet Whitney impacted thousands of students in her 32-year career, and we are grateful for this lasting gift in her memory that will continue her legacy by inspiring students to follow her career path,” he added.

In Oregon City schools, the AVID college preparedness program helps students prepare for college success, by building skills and supporting students in pursuing challenging coursework. Most students in the program do not come from college-going families, so the program provides opportunities for students to visit university campuses starting in middle school.

AVID students from Gardiner and Ogden middle schools have the opportunity to visit three campuses. Sixth graders visit Western Oregon University, seventh graders visit Oregon State, and eighth graders visit the University of Oregon.

“They have wild technology at OSU,” said Gardiner seventh grader Micheal Dayton. “I got to see how a 3D printer works.”

“College visits are a super positive experience for our students, especially because many of them will be first-generation college students,” said Gardiner teacher Danielle Tebon. “It’s transformative to see how these field trips improve students’ motivation and determination to do well in school as they become aware of the options open to them.”

Students in the bilingual program at Gardiner Middle School learn more than Spanish language skills. They also learn a lot about Spanish-speaking cultures. Bilingual teacher Keely Rock takes cultural learning to the next level by hosting an annual spring break trip to Costa Rica.

This year eight students in grades 5 to 7 joined the trip, spending 8 days traveling from the central valley of Costa Rica to the Pacific coast, including visits in San Jose, Tirimbina, La Fortuna, and Manuel Antonio.

“The goal of the trip is to introduce our students to Costa Rican culture through their use of the Spanish language,” explained Rock. “The more authentic language immersion the students can have, the better.”

Highlights of the trip included cooking classes, a canopy zip line tour through the Cloud Forest, two days at a bat research center, and visiting a school, where they played fútbol with the students and enjoyed a traditional dance performance.

Oregon City sixth graders experience a rite of passage attending outdoor school. For some it is the first time they have spent a week away from their family, been to the beach, or eaten a s’more.

The camp-like experience, partly funded by the Oregon Lottery, has been a tradition in the district for many years. Besides learning about Oregon ecosystems, students enjoy hiking, survival skills, archery and field studies.

“Science is even more amazing when you are out in nature completing hands on experiments,” said Gardiner Bilingual Science teacher Keely Rock. “From water studies and plant identification to wildlife encounters, kids realize the whole world is their classroom. They also get to see their teachers in an entirely different light. The connections that we make at outdoor school are not constrained by four walls and a bell schedule.”

“It makes me a better teacher,” said Gardiner science teacher Megan McCormick. “Outdoor School is the perfect opportunity to build relationships with our students that will maximize their learning back in the classroom."

The annual donation is party of Rotary’s commitment to supporting education and literacy.

“The kids love their dictionaries,” said Gaffney Lane teacher Jenny Lau. “They love to have dictionary races to see who can find the word first. The maps in the back get used every time we have a new story in our National Geographic Reading Program. We also use the weights and measures during our math time to see what metric and standard units we use for length, weight, temperature, and volume.”

While students were enjoying Spring Break, the school district’s bond team was hard at work on geotechnical and survey analysis of both district middle school sites in preparation for rebuilding Gardiner and renovating Ogden, two of the largest projects funded by the 2018 school bond.

The process involves taking core samples, drilling, analyzing soil capacity, and completion of earthquake analysis.

“While it will be awhile until construction is underway, I’m excited that our planning process is on time and on track,” said Bond Projects Manager Stephen Wasserberger. “This geotech work will ensure that our site design and building design are safe and cost-effective.”

High achievers in the annual read-a-thon at the Jennings Lodge and Candy Lane bilingual schools were rewarded with a visit from Oakley, a Newfoundland dog.

“Students who read the most had a chance to pet Oakley’s soft fur and learn about the Newfoundland breed while reading books to the dog,” said PTA Vice President Margey Vattiat, who coordinated the event. “This was the perfect motivator to get kids reading.”

Oakley works as a therapy dog at local hospitals and care facilities. Those interested in meeting Oakley will find him at the Oregon City Public Library on the first Friday of every month.

Beavercreek and McLoughlin music teacher Andy Morrow leads a double life. By day, he teaches music in Oregon City School District. By night, he is a children’s book author.

I Lost My Moon Cows was his first book, which he dedicated to the children of Beavercreek and John McLoughlin Elementary. In March, he was the school’s visiting author, sharing the writing and publishing process with students.

“Now he’s at work on his second book, based on the lyrics of the Beavercreek school song, which he wrote,” said Principal Cori Waufle. “Students at the school are illustrating each page, and the book will be available for families to purchase.”

A school wide penny drive by students at Gardiner Middle School raised over $2,000 for the Leukemia and Lymphoma Society in March. The school’s annual Pennies for Patients campaign has continued for at least 10 years.

“Our top class raised $573, and one family who has been personally touched by leukemia contributed $577,” said secretary Micki Vanderpool, who organized the event.

“Students learned that every penny counts, and if many kids each bring in a little, it makes a big difference. Collectively they can help others.”
